quiz_item.question: Which planet is furthest away from the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: Pluto is actually further away from the Sun than Neptune, but Pluto is a dwarf planet. Neptune is therefore the most distant of the planets

quiz_item.question: Which planet is closest to the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: What is the name of Pluto's biggest moon?
quiz_item.supplement: Charon is only half the size of Pluto, therefore the two bodies can be considered a double planet

quiz_item.question: Which planet is closer to the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: Which planet is best known for its ring system?
quiz_item.supplement: The rings of Saturn are old moons destroyed by the strong tidal forces of the large planet

quiz_item.question: Is Earth the largest planet in the Solar System?
quiz_item.supplement: The Earth belongs to a group of four terrestrial planets which have a hard surface. These planets are the smallest in the solar system, while the gas planets are much larger

quiz_item.question: Which one is bigger?
quiz_item.supplement: Moons are always smaller than their planet

quiz_item.question: How many planets are there in the Solar System?
quiz_item.supplement: The solar system has 8 planets and 2 dwarf planets

quiz_item.question: What is the warmest place in the Solar System?
quiz_item.supplement: The Sun is 15 million degrees Celsius in the center and about 5700 at the surface

quiz_item.question: Which one is furthest away from us?
quiz_item.supplement: The clouds are far away, but the Moon is about 40000 times further away!

quiz_item.question: Which planet is the heaviest?
quiz_item.supplement: Jupiter is the largest and heaviest planet. But the Sun is much greater than all the planets combined

quiz_item.question: Which planet is red?
quiz_item.supplement: Mars is red because of very small dust particles made of rusty iron

quiz_item.question: Which one is bigger?
quiz_item.supplement: If we placed the Earth at the Sun it would appear as a little spot at the surface

quiz_item.question: Is Mars made of chocolate?
quiz_item.supplement: Mars is originally the name of the Roman God of war. Nowadays, it is also the name of planets, chocolate bars and more!

quiz_item.question: Is the Milky Way made of milk?
quiz_item.supplement: In Ancient Greece, people actually thought it was made of milk, therefore the name

quiz_item.question: What is the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: Compared to other stars the Sun is only medium-sized. But it is very close to us, which is why it looks so big

quiz_item.question: What is an asteroid?
quiz_item.right_answer: A rocky body orbiting the sun
quiz_item.supplement: Asteroids can be anything between a few centimeters/inches and up to many kilometers/miles in diameter

quiz_item.question: Where is 71% of the surface covered with water?
quiz_item.supplement: The Earth is the only place we have liquid water

quiz_item.question: How big is the sun viewed from Pluto?
quiz_item.right_answer: As big as the head of a pin held at full arms length
quiz_item.wrong_answer: As big as seen from Earth
As big as an apple held at full arms length
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: On how many planets in the Solar System is life present?
quiz_item.supplement: And as of 2012 we haven't found life elsewhere at all

quiz_item.question: Is the day on Mercury short or long compared to a Mercury year?
quiz_item.supplement: On Earth we have 365 days per year. On Mercury a year and a day are almost the same length

quiz_item.question: Is water ice present on the Moon?
quiz_item.supplement: The ice on the moon will never become liquid. If it was exposed to direct sun light it would turn into vapor and disappear into space

quiz_item.question: Is there ice on Mars?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: How old is the surface of Enceladus?
quiz_item.supplement: Compared to the age of most moons and planets this is actually quite young. If the age of the solar system was as long as life time of a human, Enceladus's surface would be only 2 years old

quiz_item.question: When will Phobos collide with Mars?
quiz_item.supplement: The two moons of Mars were once asteroids. They were captured by the gravitational field of Mars.

quiz_item.question: Is Ceres heavier than all other asteroids combined?
quiz_item.supplement: Ceres and the other asteroids could have formed a planet between Mars and Jupiter, but Jupiter's strong gravitation prevented the small bodies in the asteroid belt from accreting into a planet

quiz_item.question: Which moon is fully covered with frozen water?
quiz_item.supplement: Europa is one of Jupiter's four largest moons discovered by Galileo 400 years ago.

quiz_item.question: What do you call rocks from space that land on Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: Before they hit the Earth, meteorites are called meteors

quiz_item.question: How big is Ida's moon, Dactyl?
quiz_item.supplement: Dactyl was discovered by coincidence when NASA mission Galilei returned pictures of asteroid Ida

quiz_item.question: Comets consist of...
quiz_item.supplement: When comets come close to the sun, the ice vaporizes and forms two beautiful tails: one opposing the direction of the comet's paths and the other aligned with the magnetic field of the Sun

quiz_item.question: Which planet has the shortest orbit?
quiz_item.supplement: The closer they are to the Sun, the faster planets move. Since Mercury is the innermost planet, it is also the fastest to orbit the Sun

quiz_item.question: What is the largest moon in the solar system?
quiz_item.supplement: Four of the Jupiter moons have been known for 400 years. In 1675 Danish astronomer Ole Romer used these moons to measure the speed of light.

quiz_item.question: What is an astronomical unit?
quiz_item.supplement: The Sun-Earth distance is approximately 150 million km

quiz_item.question: What is the Milky Way?
quiz_item.right_answer: The galaxy where the solar system is located
quiz_item.supplement: The Milky Way contains the Sun and roughly 100 billion stars. We can see only 5000 of them with the naked eye

quiz_item.question: How many days does Earth take to travel around the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: One orbit around the Sun is also called a year!

quiz_item.question: Which planet has a moon named Triton?
quiz_item.supplement: Triton is the only large moon in the Solar System that travels opposite to the rotational direction of its planet

quiz_item.question: Which planet is also sometimes called the morning star?
quiz_item.supplement: Since Venus is closer to the Sun than us, it can either be seen early in the morning or early in the evening, but never in the middle of the night

quiz_item.question: Which planet moves fastest around the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: On which planet's surface is the pressure 100 times higher than on Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: The high pressure works as a blanket keeping Venus' surface at the same temperature all around the globe, day or night. The temperature on Venus only varies about 1 degree Celsius

quiz_item.question: Which one has the strongest greenhouse effect?
quiz_item.supplement: Venus atmosphere is 100 times denser than Earth's and consists of nearly pure CO2. This greenhouse effect is so intense that Venus is actually hotter than Mercury (which is closest to the Sun)

quiz_item.question: Which is the greatest body in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter?
quiz_item.supplement: Ceres holds one third of the mass in the asteroid belt, which in total weighs less than the Moon

quiz_item.question: How many Apollo astronauts have walked on the Moon?
quiz_item.supplement: Six NASA missions landed humans on the moon, with three astronauts on each mission. The third astronaut stayed in orbit waiting for the other two to come back from the moon

quiz_item.question: When did humans last stand on the Moon?
quiz_item.supplement: Apollo 17 was the final mission of the Apollo program

quiz_item.question: Which is the warmest planet in the solar system?
quiz_item.supplement: The strong greenhouse effect is the reason why Venus is so hot

quiz_item.question: How many moons does Jupiter have?
quiz_item.supplement: The number of known moons around Jupiter is constantly increasing as better telescopes and satellite missions to the outer planet makes it possible to discover the smaller moons

quiz_item.question: Where is life more likely to be found?
quiz_item.supplement: Below the frozen surface, Europa may be hosting a sea of liquid water. Europa also has a source of energy - the tidal force from Jupiter. On the other planets it is too hot or too cold for life to exist

quiz_item.question: How long has life existed on Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: Life seems to have evolved on Earth as soon as conditions here allowed it. Through most of Earth's history, life has been present in the form of microbial organisms

quiz_item.question: Were Phobos and Deimos once asteroids?
quiz_item.supplement: Other asteroids might also have been captured by Mars' gravitational field, but we don't know that for sure

quiz_item.question: How many Moon rocks did the Apollo astronauts bring home?
quiz_item.supplement: In the same period unmanned Russian spacecraft brought about 300 grams of material from the Moon back to Earth. These rare samples have given a lot of new knowledge about the Moon and how it formed

quiz_item.question: How high is air pressure at the surface of Venus?
quiz_item.supplement: Spacecrafts that landed on Venus typically last only about 1 hour because of the high pressure and the high temperature. This makes it very difficult to explore Venus!

quiz_item.question: Do we have pieces of Vesta's former parent body on Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: The Howardite, Eucrite and Diogenite meteorites come from a differentiated parent body in the asteroid belt, perhaps the asteroid Vesta. It is still debated whether these meteorites and Vesta share the same origin

quiz_item.question: Are there any moons in our solar system not in this app?
quiz_item.supplement: Many actually. But a number of the moons are small and not very well known

quiz_item.question: Which mission was first to land on Mars?
quiz_item.supplement: NASA's Viking 1 and 2 missions were launched in 1975 and were first to successfully land on Mars in 1976

quiz_item.question: What is the greatest danger for astronauts in space?
quiz_item.supplement: Without the protective ozone-layer, UV radiation or a protective space suit, both x-ray flares from the Sun and cosmic rays from interstellar space can kill you

quiz_item.question: Which one is larger?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: Which one is larger?
quiz_item.supplement: Being a planet, Venus is larger than the asteroids and one of Mars' tiny moons

quiz_item.question: Where has no spacecraft ever landed?
quiz_item.supplement: An Apollo mission visited the Moon in the 1969-1972. The Huygens mission visited Titan in 2005. Mars' surface has been explored since the Viking mission in 1976, but no space craft has ever landed on the saturnian moon, Dione

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this moon?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this asteroid?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this planet?
quiz_item.supplement: none

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this comet?
quiz_item.supplement: NASA's Deep Impact probe visited comet Temple 1 in 2005. Part of the probe was launched to crash into the comet, while the other part measured the chemical constituents of the bright spray from the impact site

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this moon?
quiz_item.supplement: Powerful volcanic eruptions have been observed in the outer solar system on Io, Triton and Enceladus. Analyses of the gases spewed revealed that Enceladus is hiding liquid water under its icy surface

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this asteroid?
quiz_item.supplement: On its way to Eros in 1997, space shuttle NEAR passed by Mathilde. Rocks from space found on Earth are called meteorites. Most meteorites have the same composition as Mathilde

quiz_item.question: What is the name of this planet?
quiz_item.supplement: Mercury rotates so slowly that a day on Mercury is longer than its year. In the equatorial regions temperatures reach 430ºC at daytime and -185ºC at night

quiz_item.question: What was the name of this impacting comet?
quiz_item.supplement: The picture shows the collision of comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 and Jupiter in 1994. All major telescopes observed this cosmic event. The collision released more energy than stored in the world's entire nuclear arsenal

quiz_item.question: What is this?
quiz_item.supplement: The image is of the Comet Halley

quiz_item.question: What is this?
quiz_item.supplement: The sun is a star - classified as a main sequence G2V "yellow dwarf", because its visible radiation is most intense in the yellow-green portion of the spectrum

quiz_item.question: What are these?
quiz_item.supplement: In 1993 NASA space shuttle Galilei shot this picture of asteroid Ida and its tiny moon, Dactyl. A pure coincidence revealed this little moon on the photographs. Dactyl measures just 1 mile across in its longest dimension

quiz_item.question: Which one is hotter at the surface?
quiz_item.supplement: Venus is closer to the Sun and therefore hotter. It also suffers from strong greenhouse warming

quiz_item.question: Why do we not have a better picture of Proteus?
quiz_item.right_answer: No space mission has ever taken a better one
quiz_item.supplement: Voyager 1 and 2 are the only spacecraft that travelled beyond Uranus and Neptune. We know of eight moons of Neptune. Many were first discovered when Voyager 2 flew by Neptune in 1989. Proteus is so far the largest one. Yet, no better pictures have ever been taken.

quiz_item.question: What is the real name of the "Pizza Moon"?
quiz_item.supplement: Io's volcanic activity is greater than anywhere else in the solar system. Its volcanoes produce plumes of sulfur that give the moon its yellow color. Some volcanoes are higher than Mount Everest and eject lava directly into space.

quiz_item.question: Which near-Earth asteroid presents a risk of collision with Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: Eros is currently a Mars-crosser asteroid, but dynamical simulations suggest that it could develop into an Earth-crosser asteroid in "just" 2 million years

quiz_item.question: When did Shoemaker-Levy-9 break apart and collide with Jupiter?
quiz_item.supplement: The event was expected to happen. Therefore many telescopes closely followed the collision to take high-resolution images of this event

quiz_item.question: How often does Halley's comet travel by the Earth towards the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: Edmond Halley was the first to study the comet in 1705. He predicted that it would come back 75 years later. Most people didn't believe him but he turned out to be right

quiz_item.question: What is the name of the large crater on Mimas?
quiz_item.supplement: The crater was discovered in 1789 and is the largest crater in the solar system relative to its host planet

quiz_item.question: How much of Earth's surface is covered with water?
quiz_item.supplement: The water on Earth is mostly at the surface. Actually, water only accounts for 1% or less of Earth's mass

quiz_item.question: Where does the sun rise in the west and set in the east?
quiz_item.supplement: This is because Venus rotates very slowly. So the day is longer than a year!

quiz_item.question: One hemisphere of Callisto is constantly facing Jupiter. This is called...
quiz_item.supplement: Many moons rotates one time every orbit around the planet. Can you imagine what it would be like if Earth rotated around the Sun this way?

quiz_item.question: What are Saturn's rings made of?
quiz_item.supplement: The rings can be seen from Earth with a telescope. If you have a telescope or know someone who has, you can try it yourself

quiz_item.question: What kept humans from exploring the surface of Titan before the 2004 Cassini-Huygens mission?
quiz_item.wrong_answer: Titan is always hiding behind Saturn
quiz_item.supplement: NASA's Huygens probe landed on the surface of Titan. The probe recorded sounds from this distant world

quiz_item.question: What is special about Iapetus?
quiz_item.right_answer: Its surface is yin-yang, both black and white
quiz_item.wrong_answer: Its surface is turned inside out
Its shape is like a dog's bone
quiz_item.supplement: Iapetus is in synchronous rotation around Saturn. The equatorial part of the leading hemisphere is black and it is snow-white at the poles and the trailing hemisphere. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain this: one is that water can vaporize at the equator leaving dark material behind, while water is frozen at the much colder poles

quiz_item.question: How many Saturn moons do we know of?
quiz_item.supplement: Many moons are so small that they can only be observed from spacecraft traveling to Saturn

quiz_item.question: What is Uranus' moon, Ariel, and most other moons of outside Jupiter made of?
quiz_item.supplement: Water (H2O) is a major constituent in the outer solar system and a quite abundant molecule in the universe. This is because water is built up of hydrogen and oxygen, which are commonly produced in stars

quiz_item.question: How big is the wind system visible in this image of Neptune?
quiz_item.supplement: Look at the picture of Neptune and try and guess how much bigger Neptune is than Earth!

quiz_item.question: How much energy was released, when comet Shoemaker-Levy-9 collided with Jupiter?
quiz_item.right_answer: More than our entire nuclear arsenal
quiz_item.wrong_answer: Less than our entire nuclear arsenal
Same as our entire nuclear arsenal
quiz_item.supplement: Collisions release enormous amounts of energy - even when a small comet, such as SL-9, collides. The Moon formed after a giant collision between protoplanets the size of Venus and Mars. Can you imagine what a violent birth this would have been?

quiz_item.question: What will happen to Triton when it gets too close to Neptune?
quiz_item.right_answer: Tidal break up. It forms of a ring like Saturn
quiz_item.wrong_answer: A gravity assist will lead to escape
quiz_item.supplement: It is also believed that Saturn's rings are remnants of moons broken down by tidal forces

quiz_item.question: When did/will Voyager 2 pass by Proteus?
quiz_item.supplement: NASA's Voyager 2 shuttle was launched from Florida in 1977. How long was then the travel to Proteus?

quiz_item.question: Who was the first living creature in space?
quiz_item.supplement: Monkeys were also used as some of the first astronauts. Animals were sent out first because nobody knew how space would affect humans

quiz_item.question: Which planet has no ring?
quiz_item.supplement: Only the giant planets have rings. Rings of dust and small boulders orbit the larger planets because their strong gravitational field attract material, but also prevent moons from accreting close to the planet (tidal forces are too strong within the Roche limit, roughly 1 planetary radii from the planet)

quiz_item.question: What is a shooting star?
quiz_item.right_answer: A meteor passing into the Earth's atmosphere
quiz_item.supplement: Meteors enter the atmosphere at a speed of tens of kilometer per sec - that is tens of thousands km/h. At those tremendous speeds the air in the atmosphere is severely compressed and heats up the rock so it starts to burn

quiz_item.question: How long will it take NASA spacecraft New Horizons to reach Pluto?
quiz_item.supplement: New Horizon is the first mission with the main goal to study Pluto and other objects in the Kuiper Belt (outer asteroid belt)

quiz_item.question: Are there planets outside our own solar system orbiting distant stars?
quiz_item.supplement: First discovered in early 1990s, we now know of hundreds of extraterrestrial planets orbiting distant stars. We still cannot observe the planets directly from telescopes, but there are several techniques to see how they affect their mother star. Therefore we can detect them indirectly

quiz_item.question: Which planet orbits around the Moon?
quiz_item.supplement: We usually think of moons orbiting planets and not vice versa. Yet, the Earth and Moon are circulating each other in their orbit around the Sun

quiz_item.question: Where in the solar system are the most powerful volcanoes?
quiz_item.supplement: The powerful eruptions on Io eject material from its interior directly into space

quiz_item.question: Where in the solar system is the largest volcano, Olympus Mons?
quiz_item.supplement: Olympus Mons is almost 22 km high and the base is as large as France or the state of Texas. On Earth a volcano could never grow so large, simply because it would collapse under its own weight

quiz_item.question: Which spacecraft visited Uranus?
quiz_item.supplement: There has been very few missions to the outer solar system, so our knowledge about these planets is limited.

quiz_item.question: Which planet is tipped over, rolling like a ball in its orbit around the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: Imagine what seasons on Earth would be like if we were rolling like this!

quiz_item.question: Neptune's winds are the strongest in the solar system. They have blown at...
quiz_item.supplement: For comparison, the strongest wind ever recorded on Earth is 372 km/h. We don't even have a name for that wind speed!

quiz_item.question: What are Mars' two moons?
quiz_item.wrong_answer: Left over debris from a giant impact
quiz_item.supplement: The origin of Phobos and Deimos is still controversial, but they are chemically similar to some asteroids. Phobos is orbiting so close that it will end in a collision with Mars

quiz_item.question: When and by who was Pluto discovered?
quiz_item.supplement: Pluto was first regarded as the ninth planet. We now know that Pluto was the first object found among other plutoids in the Kuiper Belt

quiz_item.question: Which planet's atmosphere contains 21 percent molecular oxygen?
quiz_item.supplement: Oxygen is essential for life. When astronauts travel in space, they have to bring oxygen from Earth (or make it on their journey through energy-intensive processes like electrolysis)

quiz_item.question: Which of these planets have no moons?
quiz_item.supplement: Venus has no moon, but we still don't know why. One hypothesis suggests that Venus had a Moon formed from a gigantic collision like Earth's Moon, but a second giant collision let them both escape. This could also explain why Venus spins the opposite way around itself

quiz_item.question: Which of these planets have no moons?
quiz_item.supplement: Mercury has no moon. Planet formation is thought to proceed as larger and larger planetesimals and protoplanets collide. The existence of Earth's moon could simply be a result of chance. Mercury is small and close to the Sun, and thus hasn't been captured and kept any smaller asteroids in orbit after its formation

quiz_item.question: Which Jupiter moon has also experienced tectonics, like Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: Tectonic break-up of a planet's crust and movement of crustal layers atop each other (thrust faults) have been observed on all the inner planets and on several moons, including Ganymede, Enceladus, Europa and Ganymede.

quiz_item.question: When did the solar system form?
quiz_item.supplement: The age of the solar system is determined by age dating meteorites. This is done by measuring radioactive elements in the meteorites

quiz_item.question: Why don't Tethys, Calypso and Telesto collide, since they share orbit around Saturn?
quiz_item.right_answer: They move at the same speed
quiz_item.wrong_answer: They are so small that they always miss each other
quiz_item.supplement: If a moon orbits at a certain distance to a planet, it will also move at a certain speed. Otherwise, it will leave its orbit

quiz_item.question: Where is it bright all summer long?
quiz_item.supplement: This is because the rotation axis of Uranus is tilted 90 degrees, so that each hemisphere is pointing towards the Sun during summer. Can you imagine how the Sun moves across the Uranian sky?

quiz_item.question: How do we know the age of Oberon's surface?
quiz_item.supplement: Craters form from impactors and impact frequency was higher in the earliest ages of the solar system. An old surface is therefore densely space with craters compared to a young one. On Earth, wind and rain is constantly eroding and cleaning the surface, leaving no traces of the oldest craters.

quiz_item.question: Why does Miranda look so special?
quiz_item.right_answer: Collisions may have torn Miranda apart
quiz_item.supplement: Violent collisions with other bodies can have traumatic consequences for moons and planets

quiz_item.question: Pluto is one of many bodies in the outer asteroid belt (Kuiper belt). What is its current status?
quiz_item.supplement: The main difference between a planet and a dwarf planet is that a dwarf planet shares its orbit around the Sun with other smaller bodies

quiz_item.question: Are there aliens?
quiz_item.supplement: We simply don't know, because we have neither found any traces of extraterrestrial life or documented contact with any aliens, but we are still looking...

quiz_item.question: What is the nearest star to Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: The Sun is a star like many other stars. It looks much bigger than stars in the heavens, because we are much closer to it

quiz_item.question: Can humans travel and live anywhere outside the Earth without space suits?
quiz_item.supplement: Strong UV radiation, no breathable atmosphere and charged particle flux from the Sun will immediately kill un-protected humans at 10-100s of kilometers above our heads! Earth is actually a very nice and safe place to be

quiz_item.question: How big is the Universe?
quiz_item.wrong_answer: As big as the milky way
quiz_item.supplement: The Universe started forming 13.7 billion years ago with the Big Bang. Since then, it expanded with the speed of light and is therefore 13.7 billion light years old

quiz_item.question: Are there any planets in our solar system not in this app?
quiz_item.supplement: All eight planets in the solar system are presented in this app. Explore it yourself when finishing this game

quiz_item.question: Has any astronaut ever seen an Earth rise from the Moon?
quiz_item.right_answer: Impossible: the Moon is always facing the Earth
quiz_item.wrong_answer: They were there, but not during Earth rise
No man has ever been on the Moon
quiz_item.supplement: You may think you have seen a picture of Earth-rise from the moon. However, the famous picture "Earth-rise" was taken onboard NASA Apollo 8 mission in 1968.

quiz_item.question: Is there water ice present on all planet surfaces?
quiz_item.right_answer: No, Mercury is too close to the sun
quiz_item.wrong_answer: No, Earth is the only one
quiz_item.supplement: Water ice can only persist at temperatures below freezing point (approximately 0 degrees Celsius depending on pressure)

quiz_item.question: Why is Mars red?
quiz_item.supplement: The iron on Mars tells us that the planet in a relatively oxidized state. That is why it is rusty-colored

quiz_item.question: Mercury is closer to the sun than Venus, so why is Venus hotter?
quiz_item.wrong_answer: Heat is flowing from its interior
quiz_item.supplement: The distance to the Sun is not the only thing that matters to atmospheric temperature. Greenhouse warming works as a blanket

quiz_item.question: Which of the following is not unique for Earth?
quiz_item.supplement: Jupiter's moon Europa hides an ocean below its surface

quiz_item.question: Which one is closer to the sun?
quiz_item.supplement: none
